metadata.title: A new method to improve the properties of recycled aggregate concrete: Composite addition of basalt fiber and nano-silica

sections.text:
lable at ScienceDirect
Contents lists avai
Journal of Cleaner Production
journal homepage: www.elsevier .com/locate/ jc lepro
A new method to improve the properties of recycled aggregate concrete: Composite addition of basalt fiber and nano-silica
Yonggui Wang a, b, *, Peter Hughes a, Haicheng Niu a, Yuhui Fan a
a School of Civil Engineering, Henan Polytechnic University, Jiaozuo, 454000, China b Henan Province Engineering Laboratory for Eco-architecture and the Built Environment, Jiaozuo, 454000, China
a r t i c l e i n f o
Article history: Received 16 March 2019 Received in revised form 27 June 2019 Accepted 9 July 2019 Available online 11 July 2019
Handling Editor: Vladimir Strezov
Keywords: Recycled aggregate concrete Recycled aggregates replacement ratio Basalt fiber Nano-silica Mechanical properties Microstructure
* Corresponding author. School of Civil Engineerin sity, Jiaozuo, 454000, China.
E-mail address: wangyonggui@hpu.edu.cn (Y. Wan
https://doi.org/10.1016/j.jclepro.2019.07.077 0959-6526/© 2019 Elsevier Ltd. All rights reserved.
a b s t r a c t
Use of recycled aggregate manufactured from waste concrete to produce new concrete could reduce the use of natural gravel, and the quantity and area of landfills, which is conducive to natural environmental protection and economic development. How to effectively reduce the hazards of construction waste is an urgent problem to be solved. Recycled aggregate concrete is one of the effective ways to realize the utilization of resources. This paper provides a new method for the resource utilization of construction waste, which is helpful for expanding the range of engineering applications for recycled aggregate concrete. The recycled aggregate concrete was reinforced with basalt fiber and nano-silica, and its mechanical properties, including compressive strength, splitting tensile strength and flexural strength were tested. Meanwhile, the microstructure of the recycled aggregate concrete was analyzed by scanning electron microscopy (SEM), X-ray diffraction (XRD) and energy dispersive spectroscopy (EDS). It was found that basalt fibers and nano-silica improve the recycled aggregate concrete. Nano-silica is beneficial for enhancing the bonding of the basalt fibers and cement matrix. The appropriate content of nano-silica was conducive to the improvement of the recycled aggregate concrete density and the performance of the interface transition zone, thereby increasing the bridge effect of the fibers. When the nano-silica content was high, the calcium-silicon ratio increased, and the concrete density decreased. In terms of the compressive strength and microstructures, when the recycled aggregate replacement ratio was no more than 50%, the optimum nano-silica content was 6%, and when the recycled aggregate replacement ratio was 100%, the optimum nano-silica content was 8%. The addition of basalt fiber and nano-silica is conducive to expanding the scope of engineering applications for recycled aggregate concrete and improving the natural environment, which is helpful to the sustainability of the construction industry.
© 2019 Elsevier Ltd. All rights reserved.

sections.heading: 1. Introduction
sections.text:
Recently, with the rapid development of infrastructure and urbanization in China, the demand for concrete continues to grow. At the same time, natural disasters and the demolition of old buildings have generated a large amount of construction waste, which poses great challenges to environmental protection and sustainable development (Silva et al., 2017). Garbage is a misplaced resource, from this point of view, recycling of construction waste can effectively alleviate this challenge, and recycled aggregate concrete (RAC) comes into being. RAC refers to the concrete in which the
g, Henan Polytechnic Univer-
g).
natural aggregate (NA) is partially or fully replaced with recycled aggregates (RA). RAC can reduce the use of NA, and the quantity and area of landfills, which is conducive to environmental protection and economic development (Marinkovi c et al., 2017; Xiao et al., 2012). However, compared with natural aggregate concrete (NAC), the mechanical properties of RAC are quite different, and the mechanical properties of RAC decrease with increasing RA content (Paranhos et al., 2016; Yildirim et al., 2015).
The failure characteristics of RAC and NAC were similar (Lima et al., 2013), but, some RAC properties were not as good as those of NAC (Bravo et al., 2015; Kou et al., 2012). Compared to NA, RA has a higher porosity and water absorption, lower density and strength, and aweaker adhesion performance of the interface transition zone (ITZ) (Rodríguez et al., 2016). Because of the higher water absorption, the workability of RAC is lower than that of NAC (Behera et al., 2014; Salesa et al., 2017). Wagih et al. (2013) analyzed the influence
of the RA replacement ratio on the mechanical properties of RAC. The results showed that when the RA replacement ratio was 25%, 50%, 75% and 100%, compared to NAC, the compressive strength decreased by 3.5%, 13.3%, 32.9%, 40.0%, respectively. This change indicated that the higher the RA replacement ratio was, the more the compressive strength decreased. As the RA replacement ratio increases, the split tensile strength of RAC decreases (Ajdukiewicz and Kliszczewicz, 2002). Rao et al. (2007) found that when the RA replacement ratio was 100%, the reduction in the split tensile strength was up to 24%; however, the flexural strength was almost unaffected by the RA replacement ratio. However, the results of Yang et al. (2008) showed that the flexural strength decreased by 15%e20% when the RA replacement ratio was up to 100%.
It is known that RAC contains more ITZs than NAC; moreover, the adhesion performance of ITZ is weak (Shi et al., 2016), which has a serious effect on the mechanical properties of the concrete. Therefore, there are two approaches to enhance the mechanical properties of RAC and promote its engineering application. One way is to add fibers in the RAC, namely, glass fiber (Mastali et al., 2016), polypropylene fiber (Hesami et al., 2016; Mohseni et al., 2017), basalt fiber (BF) (Liu et al., 2017), steel fiber (Carneiro et al., 2014; Senaratne et al., 2016). Fiber crosses the ITZ and acts as a bridge to improve the performance of the ITZ. BF has been studied by many scholars due to its excellent properties, including, noncarcinogenicity, non-toxicity and environmental friendliness. Some studies were reported on enhancing the mechanical properties of BF-reinforced concrete (High et al., 2015; Jiang et al., 2014). Due to its small diameter, BF can effectively retard the formation and expansion of early primary microcracks, and passivate the stress concentration at the tip of the original microcracks, significantly improving the ductility of ordinary concrete (Alnahhal and Aljidda, 2018), preventing the generation and expansion of microcracks inside the mortar, and improving the crack resistance of the fiber mortar (Asprone et al., 2014). It was shown that the compressive strength was increased when the BF content was between 0.1% and 0.5% by volume (Elshafie and Whittleston, 2015). The mechanical properties of concrete reinforced with BF for three kinds of mass amounts, 1, 2, and 4 kgm 3, were studied by Fathima (2014). The results showed that the compressive strength, splitting tensile strength and flexural strength of NAC reinforced with BF for a mass dosage of 4 kgm 3 increased 14%, 62%, and 54%, respectively, compared to NAC without BF. The research (Katkhuda and Shatarat, 2017) used BF for five kinds of volume amounts: 0.1%, 0.3%, 0.5%,1% and 1.5%. The results showed that the BF increased the compressive strength, splitting tensile strength and flexural strength of the RAC. The optimum BF content for the compressive strength, splitting tensile strength and flexural strength of RAC was 0.5%, 0.5% and 0.3%, respectively. Dong et al. (2017) enhanced RAC with BF, with BF contents of 1, 2, and 4 kgm 3. The compressive strength, splitting tensile strength and flexural strength of the RAC at a 50% RA replacement ratio were reduced when the BF was added.
Another way to increase the RAC properties is by adding fine mineral particles, including micro-fume (Pedro et al., 2017; Shi et al., 2012) and nano-materials (Hosseini et al., 2011), to enhance the adhesion of the ITZ. The fine mineral particles exist as filler materials in the pores of the ITZ, and the secondary hydration products produced by the pozzolanic reaction of these fine mineral particles further fill in the pores and capillary spaces, increasing the density of the concrete. The compressive strength of the RAC was increased by adding micro-fume (Kou et al., 2008). Compared to silica fume, nano-materials have a smaller particle size. In previous studies, the mechanical properties and the microstructure of RAC can be enhanced by the use of nano-materials. The nano-material types include nano-SiO2 (Bernal et al., 2018; Hosseini et al., 2011),
nano-TiO2 (Mohseni et al., 2016), nano-Al2O3 (Le on et al., 2014), nano-Fe2O3 (Oltulu and Sahin, 2013), and nano-limestone (Li et al., 2015). Compared with other nano-materials, nano-SiO2 (NS) can be considered the most frequently used in improving the performance of concrete (Akhtar and Sarmah, 2018; Li et al., 2017a). The NS particles are widely used in engineering because of their characteristics, namely, smaller particle sizes, larger specific surface area, and higher activity. Adding an appropriate amount of NS in the concrete matrix was mainly helpful to achieve the following purposes (Stefanidou and Papayianni, 2012): promoting cement hydration; producing CeSeH gel beneficial for increasing concrete density and reducing porosity the ITZ; filling the pores between the cement slurry and the CeSeH gel, reducing the porosity and improving the internal structure; and controlling the degree of crystallization through transforming CH crystals to CeSeH. When the NS dosage is proper, the NS particles can form a dense structure by transforming CH crystals into CeSeH, thereby making the cement matrix more uniform and compact. Studies have shown that the microstructure of RAC mixed with NS is significantly compacted due to its pozzolanic effect and filling effect; at the same time, the compressive, flexural, and tensile strength are increased (Li et al., 2016; Mukharjee and Barai, 2014a; Younis and Mustafa, 2018). The compressive strength of RAC reached that of NAC when the NS content was 3% in the RAC (Hosseini et al., 2011). At the same time, the compressive strength was increased by 21.6% as the NS content was 2% in the RAC (Li et al., 2016). Younis and Mustafa (2018) found that, for RAC with a 50% RA replacement ratio, the compressive strength with 1.2% NS and the splitting tensile strength with 0.8% NS were higher compared to those of NAC.
The above research showed that NS could refine the pore size, enhance the microstructure, and improve the ITZ properties (Kim et al., 2018; Li et al., 2017b); BF crosses the ITZ and acts as a bridge to improve the performance of the ITZ. To improve the friction of the fibers and give full play to the bridging effect of fibers, some scholars have used BF and NS to reinforce NAC. The research by Urkhanova et al. (2015) showed that the compressive strength and splitting tensile strength were improved by adding an appropriate amount of BF and NS to NAC. However, there are few studies on the mechanical properties of RAC composites reinforced with BF and NS. Therefore, there is a necessity for research to be performed in this regard.
Since only a few studies have addressed enhancing the performance of RAC by adding BF and NS, the purpose of this study was to provide an effective technology for expanding the engineering application of RAC, and to analyze the effect of BF and NS on the mechanical properties and microstructure properties of RAC and to reveal the composite enhancement mechanism of BF and NS to RAC. In this paper, the mechanical properties of RAC, including the cubic compressive strength, axial compressive strength, splitting tensile strength and flexural strength at 28 days were analyzed with the variation of the RA replacement ratio, BF and NS content. Moreover, the microstructure of RAC at 28 days was investigated using SEM, XRD and EDS. The results should enrich the methods to enhance the properties of RAC and to promote the application of RAC in civil engineering.

sections.heading: 2.1. Materials
sections.text:
The cement used in this paper was a kind of Portland cement (P.O 42.5), which was manufactured by Jiaozuo Danyang Cement Company. Table 1 shows the physical and mechanical properties of the cement. The chopped basalt fibers were provided by Haining
Anjie Composite Materials Company. The physical properties of the BF, as shown in Table 2, were supplied by the manufacturer. The NS particles were provided by Nangong Ruiteng Alloy Material Company. The physical properties of NS were supplied by the manufacturer and are shown in Table 3. From the XRD pattern (see Fig. 1), it can be found that the particle size of the NS particles is approximately 20 nm. Medium-sized river sand was used as the fine aggregate, and the fineness modulus and apparent density were 2.46 and 1996 kgm 3, respectively. Two types of coarse aggregates were used in this paper: NA and RA, and the physical properties of the coarse aggregates are shown in Table 4. The NA was continuously graded gravel, and the RA was crushed from the waste concrete component of the structural laboratory of the School of Civil Engineering of Henan Polytechnic University. According to the Chinese Standard (GB/T 50107e2010), the strength grade of the waste concrete was C30. Urban tap water was used.

sections.heading: 2.2. Mixing
sections.text: To analyze the influence of the BF and NS content on the mechanical properties and the microstructure of RAC, the RA replacement ratio and the BF and NS content were used as control parameters. The RA replacement ratio is the volume content of RA to the total coarse aggregate, and the RA replacement ratios included 0%, 50%, and 100%. Four kinds of BF content, i.e., 0 kgm 3, 1 kgm 3, 2 kgm 3 and 3 kgm 3, were applied. In addition, four portions of NS (0%, 3%, 6% and 8%) were applied in this study, in which the NS content is the mass ratio of the NS to the cement. Based on the above factors, 48 mixtures were designed to compare the effect of different BF and NS contents on the mechanical properties and the microstructure of RAC with the different RA replacement ratios. The mix design was carried out according to Chinese Standard (JGJ55-2011). The concrete mixture proportions are summarized in Table 5. In Table 5, the mix number contains three sets of digits, among them, the first set of digits represents the RA replacement ratio, the next set of digits represents the BF content, and the last set of digits represents the NS content. For example, the number R50-3-6 indicates that the RA replacement ratio is 50%, BF content is 3 kgm 3, and the NS content is 6% in mix proportion. As shown in Table 4, RA possesses a higher water absorption rate than NA. To eliminate the influence of different water absorption, the coarse aggregate was immersed in water for 24 h before mixing, and the saturated surface of the coarse aggregate was dried and then mixed.

sections.heading: 2.3. Sample preparation
sections.text:
To ensure uniform dispersion of the BF and NS, as shown in previous studies (Amin and El-Hassan, 2015; Fang et al., 2018; Medina et al., 2014), the concrete was mixed by the sectional
feeding method. The following steps were conducted:
(1) Putting the RA into half of the water and mixing them for 2min at a normal mixing rate. (2) Adding the NS particles to the rest of the water and rapidly stirring them for 2min. (3) Putting the NS slurry of step (2) into the mixture of step (1) and stirring at a normal rate for 2min. (4) Putting the BF into the cement and mixing them at a normal rate for 2min. (5) Putting the fine aggregate into the dry mix of step (4) and stirring them at a normal rate for 2min. (6) Adding the dry mix of step (5), followed by the rest of the water and the total NA into the mixture of step (3) and mixing for 3min.
After the above steps, the slump was measured immediately, and the results are shown in Table 5. Then, the mixture was placed into the molds, vibrated using the vibrating table for 4min, transported to the floor of the curing room at a temperature of 20± 1 C, and then covered with plastic sheeting. All specimens were demolded after 24 h of casting, and then immersed in a standard water tank. Before the test, the specimens were removed from the water tank and placed in the shade. Three types of specimens were made: 100 100 100 mm cube, 100 100 300 mm prism, and 100 100 400 mm prismatic beams. Among them, the 100 100 100 mm cubic specimens contain two groups, which were used to test the compression strength and splitting tensile strength at 28 days. The prism specimens and the prismatic beams were used to test the axial compression strength and the four-point flexural strength at 28 days. The above test procedures were based on the Chinese Standard (GB/T50081-2002). At the same time, by aid of the microscopic testing methods, including SEM, XRD, and EDS, the influence of the BF and NS content on themicrostructure of the RAC at 28 days was analyzed.

sections.heading: 3.1. Slump
sections.text:
Slump can directly reflect the fluidity of concrete and is one of the important indicators of concrete performance. The statistical values of slump of the RAC are shown in Table 5. As the RA replacement ratio and the BF and NS content increases, the slump decreases. The main reason is that RA contains old mortar, and its surface is rougher, which reduces the workability of the concrete (Medina et al., 2014; Tam et al., 2016). BF has a larger surface area and requires more cement slurry to wrap, resulting in a decrease in the workability with increasing BF content. Meanwhile, the fibers dispersed in the concrete form a network structure, thereby
Table 3 The physical properties of the NS particles (manufacturer provided).
Particle size (nm) Specific surface area (m2$g 1) Purity (%) Bulk density (g$l 1) pH
20 200± 25 >99.9 50 9

sections.heading: 2 Degree
sections.text: inhibiting the flow of the concrete (Jiang et al., 2014). The NS particles have a larger specific surface area, contain many unsaturated bonds and have higher activity. Water molecules are more easily attracted to the surface of NS particles, and chemical bonds are generated between water molecules and nano-particles to form a silicone alcohol group (SieOH) (Hosseini et al., 2011), resulting in a decrease in theworkability with increasing NS content. At the same time, because of the small particle size of the NS particles, they easily agglomerate under the van der Waals force, resulting in a decrease in the free water content inside the concrete. With the increase in NS content, the probability of agglomeration increases. Under the combined action of the above factors, the slump of RAC reinforced with BF and NS decreases as the RA replacement ratio and the BF and NS content increase.

sections.heading: 3.2. Mechanical properties
sections.text: The mechanical properties of all mixtures at 28 days, namely, the cubic compressive strength (fcu), axial compressive strength (fcp), splitting tensile strength (fts) and flexural strength (ff), are shown in Table 5.

sections.heading: 3.2.1. Cubic compressive strength
sections.text:
The cubic compressive strength is an important indicator for evaluating the mechanical properties of concrete. As shown in Table 5, the cubic compressive strength of the RAC without BF and NS decreases when the RA replacement ratio increases. The result is consistent with the conclusions of Marie and Quiasrawi (2012). This is principally because the RAC contains multiple interfaces
compared with the NAC, including the interface between the gravel in the RA and the old mortar, the gravel in the RA and the new mortar, the newmortar and the oldmortar, and the NA and the new mortar (Xiao et al., 2012). The complex ITZ structure creates more defects inside the RAC, which is more likely to lead to bonding failure under the action of external forces, so the compressive strength is relatively low. Moreover, after artificial secondary fragmentation, the content of microcracks in the RA increases, and stress concentration is more likely to occur at the crack tip under pressure (Bassani et al., 2019; Shi et al., 2012). The bonding performance of the ITZ between the RA internal gravel and the old mortar is weak, and it is prone to bond slippage under loading (Li et al., 2017a). As the RA replacement ratio increases, the influence of these factors becomes more and more significant, and the cubic compressive strength continues to decrease.
Fibers are used primarily to achieve enhancements by the interconnection network formed by the fibers evenly dispersed in the concrete (Chan et al., 2019; High et al., 2015). However, the support effect of the network depends on the bond between the fibers and the matrix. The research showed that the basic structure of BF is tetrahedral units [MO4] (M¼ Si4þ, Al3þ) and octahedral units [MO6] (M¼ Al3þ, Mg2þ, Fe2þ) (Afroz et al., 2017). In the alkaline environment, the silica network is attacked by the hydroxyl ions, the SieOeSi linkage is broke, and the reaction of Eq. (1) occurs (Afroz et al., 2017). Thus, the interface layer of the cement paste becomes looser, and the space between the fibers and matrix increases. As a result, the bonding force between the fibers and the matrix decreases, the supporting effect of the network decreases, and the reinforcing effect of the fibers decreases.
½Si O Si þOH /½Si OH þ ½SiO (1) As shown in Table 5, when the BF content is 1 kgm 3 and 2 kgm 3, with the RA replacement ratio increasing, the compressive strength first increases and then decreases, and the RA replacement ratio corresponding to the maximum compressive strength was 50%. For example, when the BF content is 1 kgm 3 and 2 kgm 3, compared with the NAC, the compressive strength of the RACwith a 50% RA replacement ratio increases by 21.0% (R50-10 to R0-1-0) and 9.7% (R50-2-0 to R0-2-0), respectively. The main reason is that the BF in the concrete plays two main roles. One is that the reaction between the hydroxyl ions and the SieOeSi linkage causes the bondingweakness of the BF. The other is that the appropriate amount of BF is beneficial to improve the internal structure of the concrete, reduce the stress at the tip of microcracks, and then inhibit the formation and development of microcracks, which reflects the bridge connection effect of the BF (High et al., 2015). With the increase in the RA replacement ratio, the bridging effect of the BF is greater than the negative effect of the BF, and the compressive strength is thus increased. When the RA replacement ratio is 100%, the internal defects of the RAC increase
significantly, the bonding force between the BF and the matrix decreases, and the bridging effect decreases, so the compressive strength decreases. When the BF content is 3 kgm 3, as the RA replacement ratio increases, the compressive strength decreases. For example, compared with the NAC with 3 kgm 3 of BF, the compressive strength decreases by 10.4% (R50-3-0 to R0-3-0) at a 50% RA replacement ratio and decreases by 19.6% (R100-3-0 to R03-0) at a 100% RA replacement ratio. The main reason is that, first, when the BF content is high, the surface area of the BF is large and the fibers need enough slurry to encapsulate them, which makes the density of the concrete decrease, and the internal defects increase (High et al., 2015). Under load, stress concentration easily forms around the cracks, causing local damage and extending around the periphery (High et al., 2015). Second, the reaction between the hydroxyl ions and the SieOeSi linkage makes the interface layer loose and decreases the bonding force. Finally, as the RA replacement ratio increases, the pore and fracture content increases. Therefore, when the BF content is high, the compressive
strength of the RAC decreases with the RA replacement ratio increasing.
As shown in Table 5, when the NS is added alone, after adding the NS, the cubic compressive strength still decreases with the increasing of RA replacement ratio. For example, compared with the NAC at the same content of NS, i.e., 3%, 6%, and 8%, the compressive strength decreases by 22.6% (R50-0-3 to R0-0-3), 23.1% (R50-0-6 to R0-0-6), and 19.9% (R50-0-8 to R0-0-8), respectively, for mixes containing 50% RA, and by 33.5% (R100-0-3 to R00-3), 34.7% (R100-0-6 to R0-0-6), and 25.3% (R100-0-8 to R0-0-8), respectively, for mixes made with 100% RA. The main reason is that the content of the closed microcracks in RA increases with the increase in the RA replacement ratio, and the NS particles cannot effectively fill the closed microcracks. Under load, the stress concentration first occurs at the tip of the closed microcracks and then breaks through with other microcracks. As the RA replacement ratio increases, the content of the closed microcracks increases; thus, the compressive strength still decreases.
When BF and NS are added in combination, as the RA replacement ratio increases, the cubic compressive strength decreases. The main reason is that there are more closed microcracks in RA, and the NS particles cannot effectively bridge these closed microcracks. As the RA replacement ratio increases, the content of closed microcracks increases. Under the load, the stress concentration is easily formed at the tip of cracks, causing local damage and extending to the periphery (High et al., 2015). Therefore, the compressive strength decreases as the RA replacement ratio increases.
The NS particles have a higher activity and can react with CH crystals to form CeSeH gel, which effectively improves the density of the concrete. The appropriate amount of NS is beneficial for enhancing the compressive strength of the concrete (Güneyisi et al., 2015a). Nazari and Riahi (2011) found that after adding an appropriate amount of NS, approximarely 70% of the hydration products were CeSeH gels, and the pores and voids inside the concrete were filled up, leading to the concrete being more compact. Thus, the appropriate amount of NS is useful for the density and stability of concrete, thereby increasing the cubic compressive strength. From Table 5, as the NS content increases, the cubic compressive strength first increases and then decreases when the RA replacement ratio is 0% and 50%. The NS content corresponding to the maximum strength is 6%. When the RA replacement ratio is 100%, as the NS content increases, the cubic compressive strength consistently increases. The main reason is that at the lower RA replacement ratio, the internal porosity and void content of the RAC are relatively lower. The NS particles can fill the internal microcracks of the RA and be adsorbed on the surface of the RA, and the NS particles react with CH crystals to produce CeSeH gel. The performance of the ITZ is enhanced; thus, the compressive strength is increased. When the NS content is higher, some NS particles cannot react with CH crystals and directly leach as filler (Nazari and Riahi, 2011). Therefore, the excessive NS content is not conducive to increasing the cubic compressive strength. Moreover, the excessive NS content will also lead to the following defects (Nazari and Riahi, 2011): First, NS converts amorphous CeSeH gel into calcium silicate hydrate C5S6H5, and its strength is low, resulting in expansion of silicate polymer, thereby weakening the local area properties and affecting the compressive strength of the concrete. Second, the distance between nano-particles decreases due to excessive NS content. Because of the limited space, the CH crystal cannot be fully developed; as a result, the shrinkage and creep of the cement matrix increase, so the concrete is looser. Finally, the higher NS content results in a higher probability of agglomeration, poorer workability and higher entrapped air content, inhibiting the full play of the high-activity energy of the NS particles, and the density of the mixture is reduced, thus decreasing the compressive strength. When the RA replacement ratio is higher, the contents of pores and voids in concrete increase, and more NS particles are required for filling. Therefore, as the NS content increases, the compressive strength improves when the RA replacement ratio is 100%.
The load-displacement curve can reflect the deformation of the specimen, and the plastic characteristics of the specimen can be judged accordingly. Fig. 2 shows the load-displacement curves of some specimens. From Fig. 2, as the RA replacement ratio increases, the descending section of the curve tends to be gentle, and the top of the curve is gentler (see Fig. 2 (a)). When BF is simply mixed, the top and descending section of the curve is gentler (see Fig. 2 (c)). The results were also observed by Jiang et al. (2014). The top of the curve is sharper and the descending section is steeper after adding NS (see Fig. 2 (b) and (d)). The results are the same as those of Mobini et al. (2015). The results indicate that the plasticity of the specimen is enhanced by increasing the RA replacement ratio and BF content; the brittleness characteristic is improved by increasing
of the NS content.

sections.heading: 3.2.2. Axial compressive strength
sections.text:
Table 5 shows the axial compressive strength at 28 days. As the RA replacement ratio increased, there was a similar trend in the axial compressive strength and the cubic compressive strength. For example, when the RAC is reinforced with BF alone, and the BF content is 1 kgm 3 and 2 kgm 3, as the RA replacement ratio increases, the axial compressive strength first increases and then decreases. The RA replacement ratio corresponding to the maximum strength is 50%, and the axial compressive strength is increased by 13.0% (R50-1-0 to R0-1-0) and 19.5% (R50-2-0 to R0-20). This situation was also observed by Dong et al. (2017). Their research suggested that when the BF content is 4 kgm 3 and the RA replacement ratio is 50%, the axial compressive strength is 24.1% and 22.8% higher than that of RAC with 0% RA replacement ratio and 100% RA replacement ratio, respectively. Mainly because, due to the physical influence of the BF and the chemical reaction with the concrete matrix, when the RA replacement ratio is lower, the appropriate amount of BF is beneficial to inhibit the formation and propagation of microcracks, which is conducive to the bridging effect of the BF, and thus the compressive strength is increased. However, when the RA replacement ratio is 100%, the defects inside the RAC increase, the bonding of the BF to the matrix deteriorates, and thus the strength is somewhat reduced. For other mixtures, as the RA replacement ratio increases, the axial compressive strength decreases. Table 5 shows that when the RA replacement ratio is no more than 50%, the optimum NS content is 6%, and when the RA replacement ratio is 100%, the optimum NS content is 8%.
From Table 5, the ratio of the axial compressive strength to the cubic compressive strength at 28 days can be obtained. The ratio of NAC is between 0.690 and 0.875, which is slightly higher than the 0.681e0.816 ratio of the RAC. Mukharjee and Barai (2014b) showed that the ratio of RAC was slightly higher than that of NAC. Because that the brittleness of NAC is greater, the cracking load of lateral deformation is smaller, and the restraining effect of the bearing surface is weakened, so that the cubic compressive strength is slightly higher than the axial compressive strength, resulting in a higher ratio of the NAC.
Because there is a certain correspondence between the strengths of concrete, the relationship between the axial compressive strength and the cubic compressive strength is presented here, as shown in Fig. 3. The linear relationship is consistent with the results of Fang et al. (2018) and Li (2008). In the curves of Fig. 3, the linear model is used to express their relationship, and the R-squared value is also shown. The fitted value is consistent with the experimental value.

sections.heading: 3.2.3. Splitting tensile strength and flexural strength
sections.text:
In engineering, the splitting tensile test is usually used instead of the axial tensile test, and the axial tensile strength of concrete is estimated by the splitting tensile strength. The test results of the splitting tensile strength (fts) and flexural strength (ff) at 28 days are shown in Table 5.
When BF is added alone, the splitting tensile strength of the 28- day RAC first increases and then decreases as the RA replacement ratio increases, and the RA replacement ratio corresponding to the maximum tensile strength is 50%. For example, when the BF content is 1 kgm 3, 2 kgm 3, and 3 kgm 3, the splitting tensile strength is increased by 13.6% (R50-1-0 to R0-1-0), 29.8% (R50-20 to R0-2-0), and 11.0% (R50-3-0 to R0-3-0), respectively. This observation was also found by Dong et al. (2017) and Fang et al. (2018). The main reason is that when the RA replacement ratio is 100%, the defect content in the RAC is higher. At the same time, the chemical reaction between the BF and the matrix causes bond
weakness. The influence of the above factors decreases the splitting tensile strength when the RA replacement ratio is 100%. For other mixtures, the splitting tensile strength decreases as the RA replacement ratio increases. Table 5 shows that BF is advantageous
for increasing the splitting tensile strength. For example, when the BF is added at contents of 1 kgm 3 and 2 kgm 3, the splitting tensile strength increases by 5.5% (R50-1-0 to R50-0-0) and 7.7% (R50-2-0 to R50-0-0) for mixes containing 50% RA and by 1.1% (R100-1-0 to R100-0-0) and 0.6% (R100-2-0 to R100-0-0) for mixes with 100% RA. The result is consistent with the conclusions of Dong et al. (2017). Due to the small diameter, BF can effectively suppress cracks growth. As a result, the property of the ITZ is enhanced by BF. According to the above analysis, it is concluded that the BF has more influence than the NS on the splitting tensile strength of RAC.
As shown in Table 5, the flexural strength at 28 days decreases when the RA replacement ratio increases. This result is consistent with the research of Dong et al. (2017). The main reason is that the RA contains more old mortar, which has a larger difference in modulus of elasticity from the NA, and the stress distribution in the tension zone is more uneven. The microcracks first develop inside the RA or its ITZ. At the same time, there are many closed microcracks in RA. Under the external load, the tip of the closed microcracks is more likely to generate stress concentration, and it expands rapidly and then merges with other cracks. With the combined influence of the above factors, the flexural strength decreases with the increasing of the RA replacement ratio. When the RA replacement ratio is 100% and BF is doped alone, the content of the BF corresponding to themaximum flexural strength is 2 kgm 3. For example, when the BF is added at contents of 1 kgm 3, 2 kgm 3, and 3 kgm 3, compared with R100-0-0, the flexural strength increases by 1.6% (R100-1-0), 7.7% (R100-2-0), and 6.6%
(R100-3-0), respectively. The influence of the BF content provided by Dong et al. (2017) also showed that when RA replacement ratio was 100%, the flexural strength first increased and then decreased with increasing BF content and the optimum BF content was 2 kgm 3.
Fig. 4 shows the loadedeflection relationships for the RAC with different BF and NS contents. According to Fig. 4, it can be observed that for the RAC without BF, the load decreases rapidly with the increase in deflection after the peak load (see Fig. 4 (a) and (c)), whereas for the RAC with BF, the decreasing trends are flatter, the ductility has improved and the ultimate displacement has increased (see Fig. 4 (b) and (d)). The results were also observed by Asprone et al. (2014) and Branston et al. (2016). It can also be found that with increasing BF content, the descending section of the curve tends to be gentle. This is mainly attributed to the bridging effect of the BF (Dong et al., 2017). In fact, cracking is caused by the spread of defects inside the mortar or on the ITZ to the surrounding area. The matrix continuity is destroyed due to the bridging effect of the BF, thus blocking the path of the defect propagation (Asprone et al., 2014).
The relationship between the cubic compressive strength and splitting tensile strength and between the cubic compressive strength and flexural strength is shown in Fig. 5 and Fig. 6, respectively. In the curves of Figs. 5 and 6, the power function has been used to express their relationship, and the R-squared values are shown. The power function model is consistent with the results of Mukharjee and Barai (2014b). The fitted value is in good agreement with the experimental value. As shown in Figs. 3, Fig. 5, and Fig. 6, the specified strength can be predicted by other strengths.

sections.heading: 3.3.1. Bonding performance
sections.text:
As the hydroxyl ions and the SieOeSi linkage react, the space between the cementmatrix and the BF increases, the interface layer of the cement paste becomes looser, and the bonding force between the fibers and the matrix decreases (Jiang et al., 2014). The
of the cured specimens. x denotes cubic compressive strength and y denotes split tensile strength.
SEM images of the bond performance between the cement matrix and BF at 28 days are shown in Fig. 7. The loose interface layer between the cement matrix and BF is observed (see Fig. 7(a)e7(c)). This was also observed by Branston et al. (2016), whose research showed that a good bond between the cement matrix and the BF was observed at an early age, and a loose interface layer was observed at 28 days. The bond between the cement matrix and the BF is the fundamental guarantee for the enhancement of the fibers, and when the interface layer between the cement matrix and BF is
Fig. 7. SEM images of BF in the cement matrix: (a) with 1 kgm 3 BF and 0% NS; (b) with 2 kg
looser, the fiber cannot effectively play the role of network support, so the strength of the RAC is decreased. It can also be seen that the internal defects increase when the content of BF is 3 kgm 3. This phenomenon was also observed by Branston et al. (2016).
From Fig. 7, it can be seen that when NS is added, the bonding properties are enhanced (see Fig. 7(c) to Fig. 7(d)). The main reason is that NS particles react with CH in the matrix prior to the BF to form CeSeH gel, and the content of OH in the matrix decreases correspondingly (Khaloo et al., 2016).

sections.heading: 3.3.2. Nano-silica effect
sections.text:
When NS is not added, the hydration product in the RAC is a plate crystal, there are many pores between the crystals, and the structure is relatively loose. As the NS content increases, the hydration products are finer and the connections are tighter. This phenomenon is the same as that observed in the literature (Li et al., 2016), which shows that the pores become smaller and the pore content decreases after adding an appropriate amount of NS. The SEM images at 28 days of some specimens are shown in Fig. 8.
It can also be seen from Fig. 8 that after adding an appropriate amount of NS, the homogeneity of the concrete is improved, the number of pores is significantly reduced, the ITZ is strengthened, and the interior of the matrix contains more hydration products with a smaller particle size. Therefore, the addition of NS can improve the internal structure of RAC. This is due to the smaller size of the NS particles. According to the surface effect and small-size effect, the number of surface atoms increases and there are more unsaturated bonds. Therefore, the NS particles have a high surface energy and chemical activity and are easily combined with other atoms in a stable state (Güneyisi et al., 2015b). The NS particles become the non-spontaneous crystal nucleus of the cement hydration reaction through the combination of their surface atoms,
m 3 BF and 0% NS; (c) with 3 kgm 3 BF and 0% NS; and (d) with 3 kgm 3 BF and 3% NS.
forming a uniform and dense hydrated calcium silicate with NS particles as the core and filling the internal pores of the concrete; therefore, the matrix structure is relatively compact. In addition, the NS particles are bonded to the CH crystal produced by the cement hydration, and the reaction of Eq. (2) occurs. The new CeSeH gel leads to the reduction of the size and the content of CH crystal (Khaloo et al., 2016).
SiO2 þmH2Oþ nCaðOHÞ2/nCaO,SiO2,ðmþ nÞH2O (2) The continuous reaction between the NS particles and CH crystal converts into CeSeH gel with higher strength, and the CeSeH gel fills in the pores of the mortar to enhance the density of the concrete. The flocculent CeSeH gel is tightly bonded to the compound layer (Pang et al., 2016), which strengthens the bond between the matrix and the fiber and improves the performance of the ITZ. The distance between NS particles decreases with increasing NS content. Due to the limited space, CH crystals cannot be fully developed, and the amount of crystal decreases, resulting in the decrease in the crystal and the strengthening gel; and the increasing in the concrete shrinkage creep (Khaloo et al., 2016); therefore, the internal structure of the concrete is looser. Meanwhile, excessive NS may lead to agglomeration of particles, thereby reducing the surface area and dispersion of the NS particles, inhibiting the full play of the high activity energy of the NS particles. The agglomeration effect of the NS particles also reduces the workability of the concrete, affects the density of the concrete, and thus has a negative impact on the strength.
To discuss the influence of NS on cement hydration, the specimens at 28 days were analyzed by XRD. The XRD patterns of some specimens are shown in Fig. 9. The intensity diffraction peak decreases and the signal intensity related to the CH crystal decreases
after adding NS. The research shows that the intensity of the diffraction peak of a certain crystal phase decreases as the relative content of the crystal decreases (Khaloo et al., 2016). In addition, CH crystal is the main crystal phase of cement mortar, which indicates that NS inhibits the formation of CH crystals. In the XRD analysis, since the CeSeH gel crystallinity is low, its characteristic peak is wide and low, and it is difficult to distinguish. Therefore, in this paper, by combining EDS, the calcium-silicon ratio was analyzed to determine whether the hydration product is CeSeH gel or CH crystal, CeSeH gel: Ca/Si 2.5, CH crystal: Ca/Si 10 (Pang et al., 2016; Wu et al., 2016). Taking into account the different degrees
of crystallization in the new mortar and the new ITZ, during the EDS test, the points are taken in the new mortar and the new ITZ, where the points are taken along a straight line in the new mortar zone, and the points are along the transition zone in the new ITZ. The location of the points is shown in Fig. 10, and the test results of EDS are shown in Table 6.
The ratio of calcium to silicon is the largest when the NS is not doped, which is consistent with the feature of the flaky CH content in Fig. 8 (a). When NS is added, the calcium-silicon ratio decreases, and the flaky CH is scattered in SEM. The CH produced by cement hydration reacts with NS particles quickly, which reduces its enrichment level. The ratio of calcium to silicon increased when the NS content was 8%. This was due to the agglomeration phenomenon after excessive addition of NS. The gel caused by the reaction with water encapsulated the cement particles, closed part of the pores, and inhibited the hydration reaction of the cement. The Ca2þ is not effectively reduced (Wang et al., 2016). Therefore, the compressive strength decreases when the NS content is excessive.

sections.heading: 4. Conclusion
sections.text:
By analyzing the mechanical properties and microstructure of RAC reinforced with BF and NS, the conclusions are as follows:
(1) As the RA replacement ratio increases, the BF and NS content, the RAC slump and the workability decrease. As the RA replacement ratio and BF content increase, the plastic performance of the concrete is enhanced. As the NS content increases, the brittleness characteristics are improved. (2) As the RA replacement ratio increases, the cubic compressive strength of RAC without BF decreases. When BF is added alone, the RA replacement ratio corresponding to the maximum of the cubic compressive strength is 50%. When mixed with BF and NS, as the RA replacement ratio increases, the cubic compressive strength decreases. (3) When the BF content is 1 kgm 3 and 2 kgm 3, as the RA replacement ratio increases, the axial compressive strength first improves and then decreases, and the RA replacement ratio corresponding to the maximum of the axial compressive strength is 50%. The ratio of the axial compressive strength to the cubic compressive strength of the RAC is slightly smaller than that of the NAC. (4) The RA replacement ratio and BF content are themain factors affecting the splitting tensile strength and flexural strength,

sections.text: This paper was supported by the Henan Natural Science Foundation of China (182300410134) and the Henan Provincial Science and Technology Research Project of China (182102310877). Meanwhile, I would like to express my sincere thanks to Professor Zhou Miao, Wang Hui, Yu Yongqiang and Gong Jian of the School of Civil Engineering of Henan Polytechnic University for their help during the experiment. In addition, I expressed deep gratitude to Liu Fan, Zhao Ying, Li Tao and other students who participated in the experiments.

referenceMentions.context: At the same time, natural disasters and the demolition of old buildings have generated a large amount of construction waste, which poses great challenges to environmental protection and sustainable development (Silva et al., 2017).
RAC can reduce the use of NA, and the quantity and area of landfills, which is conducive to environmental protection and economic development (Marinkovi c et al., 2017; Xiao et al., 2012).

However, compared with natural aggregate concrete (NAC), the mechanical properties of RAC are quite different, and the mechanical properties of RAC decrease with increasing RA content (Paranhos et al., 2016; Yildirim et al., 2015).

However, compared with natural aggregate concrete (NAC), the mechanical properties of RAC are quite different, and the mechanical properties of RAC decrease with increasing RA content (Paranhos et al., 2016; Yildirim et al., 2015).
The failure characteristics of RAC and NAC were similar (Lima et al., 2013), but, some RAC properties were not as good as those of NAC (Bravo et al.
, 2013), but, some RAC properties were not as good as those of NAC (Bravo et al., 2015; Kou et al., 2012).
, 2013), but, some RAC properties were not as good as those of NAC (Bravo et al., 2015; Kou et al., 2012).
Compared to NA, RA has a higher porosity and water absorption, lower density and strength, and aweaker adhesion performance of the interface transition zone (ITZ) (Rodríguez et al., 2016).
Because of the higher water absorption, the workability of RAC is lower than that of NAC (Behera et al., 2014; Salesa et al., 2017).
Because of the higher water absorption, the workability of RAC is lower than that of NAC (Behera et al., 2014; Salesa et al., 2017).
As the RA replacement ratio increases, the split tensile strength of RAC decreases (Ajdukiewicz and Kliszczewicz, 2002).
It is known that RAC contains more ITZs than NAC; moreover, the adhesion performance of ITZ is weak (Shi et al., 2016), which has a serious effect on the mechanical properties of the concrete.
One way is to add fibers in the RAC, namely, glass fiber (Mastali et al., 2016), polypropylene fiber (Hesami et al.
, 2016), polypropylene fiber (Hesami et al., 2016; Mohseni et al., 2017), basalt fiber (BF) (Liu et al.
, 2016), polypropylene fiber (Hesami et al., 2016; Mohseni et al., 2017), basalt fiber (BF) (Liu et al.
, 2017), basalt fiber (BF) (Liu et al., 2017), steel fiber (Carneiro et al.
Some studies were reported on enhancing the mechanical properties of BF-reinforced concrete (High et al., 2015; Jiang et al., 2014).
Some studies were reported on enhancing the mechanical properties of BF-reinforced concrete (High et al., 2015; Jiang et al., 2014).

Due to its small diameter, BF can effectively retard the formation and expansion of early primary microcracks, and passivate the stress concentration at the tip of the original microcracks, significantly improving the ductility of ordinary concrete (Alnahhal and Aljidda, 2018), preventing the generation and expansion of microcracks inside the mortar, and improving the crack resistance of the fiber mortar (Asprone et al.

Due to its small diameter, BF can effectively retard the formation and expansion of early primary microcracks, and passivate the stress concentration at the tip of the original microcracks, significantly improving the ductility of ordinary concrete (Alnahhal and Aljidda, 2018), preventing the generation and expansion of microcracks inside the mortar, and improving the crack resistance of the fiber mortar (Asprone et al., 2014).
The research (Katkhuda and Shatarat, 2017) used BF for five kinds of volume amounts: 0.
Another way to increase the RAC properties is by adding fine mineral particles, including micro-fume (Pedro et al., 2017; Shi et al., 2012) and nano-materials (Hosseini et al.
Another way to increase the RAC properties is by adding fine mineral particles, including micro-fume (Pedro et al., 2017; Shi et al., 2012) and nano-materials (Hosseini et al.
, 2012) and nano-materials (Hosseini et al., 2011), to enhance the adhesion of the ITZ.
The compressive strength of the RAC was increased by adding micro-fume (Kou et al., 2008).
The nano-material types include nano-SiO2 (Bernal et al., 2018; Hosseini et al., 2011), nano-TiO2 (Mohseni et al.
The nano-material types include nano-SiO2 (Bernal et al., 2018; Hosseini et al., 2011), nano-TiO2 (Mohseni et al.
, 2011), nano-TiO2 (Mohseni et al., 2016), nano-Al2O3 (Le on et al.
, 2014), nano-Fe2O3 (Oltulu and Sahin, 2013), and nano-limestone (Li et al.
, 2014), nano-Fe2O3 (Oltulu and Sahin, 2013), and nano-limestone (Li et al., 2015).
Compared with other nano-materials, nano-SiO2 (NS) can be considered the most frequently used in improving the performance of concrete (Akhtar and Sarmah, 2018; Li et al., 2017a).

Adding an appropriate amount of NS in the concrete matrix was mainly helpful to achieve the following purposes (Stefanidou and Papayianni, 2012): promoting cement hydration; producing CeSeH gel beneficial for increasing concrete density and reducing porosity the ITZ; filling the pores between the cement slurry and the CeSeH gel, reducing the porosity and improving the internal structure; and controlling the degree of crystallization through transforming CH crystals to CeSeH.

Studies have shown that the microstructure of RAC mixed with NS is significantly compacted due to its pozzolanic effect and filling effect; at the same time, the compressive, flexural, and tensile strength are increased (Li et al., 2016; Mukharjee and Barai, 2014a; Younis and Mustafa, 2018).

Studies have shown that the microstructure of RAC mixed with NS is significantly compacted due to its pozzolanic effect and filling effect; at the same time, the compressive, flexural, and tensile strength are increased (Li et al., 2016; Mukharjee and Barai, 2014a; Younis and Mustafa, 2018).
The compressive strength of RAC reached that of NAC when the NS content was 3% in the RAC (Hosseini et al., 2011).
6% as the NS content was 2% in the RAC (Li et al., 2016).

The above research showed that NS could refine the pore size, enhance the microstructure, and improve the ITZ properties (Kim et al., 2018; Li et al., 2017b); BF crosses the ITZ and acts as a bridge to improve the performance of the ITZ.
To ensure uniform dispersion of the BF and NS, as shown in previous studies (Amin and El-Hassan, 2015; Fang et al., 2018; Medina et al., 2014), the concrete was mixed by the sectional
To ensure uniform dispersion of the BF and NS, as shown in previous studies (Amin and El-Hassan, 2015; Fang et al., 2018; Medina et al., 2014), the concrete was mixed by the sectional
To ensure uniform dispersion of the BF and NS, as shown in previous studies (Amin and El-Hassan, 2015; Fang et al., 2018; Medina et al., 2014), the concrete was mixed by the sectional
The main reason is that RA contains old mortar, and its surface is rougher, which reduces the workability of the concrete (Medina et al., 2014; Tam et al., 2016).
The main reason is that RA contains old mortar, and its surface is rougher, which reduces the workability of the concrete (Medina et al., 2014; Tam et al., 2016).
inhibiting the flow of the concrete (Jiang et al., 2014).

Water molecules are more easily attracted to the surface of NS particles, and chemical bonds are generated between water molecules and nano-particles to form a silicone alcohol group (SieOH) (Hosseini et al., 2011), resulting in a decrease in theworkability with increasing NS content.

5 compared with the NAC, including the interface between the gravel in the RA and the old mortar, the gravel in the RA and the new mortar, the newmortar and the oldmortar, and the NA and the new mortar (Xiao et al., 2012).

Moreover, after artificial secondary fragmentation, the content of microcracks in the RA increases, and stress concentration is more likely to occur at the crack tip under pressure (Bassani et al., 2019; Shi et al., 2012).

Moreover, after artificial secondary fragmentation, the content of microcracks in the RA increases, and stress concentration is more likely to occur at the crack tip under pressure (Bassani et al., 2019; Shi et al., 2012).
Fibers are used primarily to achieve enhancements by the interconnection network formed by the fibers evenly dispersed in the concrete (Chan et al., 2019; High et al., 2015).
Fibers are used primarily to achieve enhancements by the interconnection network formed by the fibers evenly dispersed in the concrete (Chan et al., 2019; High et al., 2015).
The research showed that the basic structure of BF is tetrahedral units [MO4] (M1⁄4 Si4þ, Al3þ) and octahedral units [MO6] (M1⁄4 Al3þ, Mg2þ, Fe2þ) (Afroz et al., 2017).

The other is that the appropriate amount of BF is beneficial to improve the internal structure of the concrete, reduce the stress at the tip of microcracks, and then inhibit the formation and development of microcracks, which reflects the bridge connection effect of the BF (High et al., 2015).

The main reason is that, first, when the BF content is high, the surface area of the BF is large and the fibers need enough slurry to encapsulate them, which makes the density of the concrete decrease, and the internal defects increase (High et al., 2015).
Under load, stress concentration easily forms around the cracks, causing local damage and extending around the periphery (High et al., 2015).
Under the load, the stress concentration is easily formed at the tip of cracks, causing local damage and extending to the periphery (High et al., 2015).
When the NS content is higher, some NS particles cannot react with CH crystals and directly leach as filler (Nazari and Riahi, 2011).

Moreover, the excessive NS content will also lead to the following defects (Nazari and Riahi, 2011): First, NS converts amorphous CeSeH gel into calcium silicate hydrate C5S6H5, and its strength is low, resulting in expansion of silicate polymer, thereby weakening the local area properties and affecting the compressive strength of the concrete.
This is mainly attributed to the bridging effect of the BF (Dong et al., 2017).
The matrix continuity is destroyed due to the bridging effect of the BF, thus blocking the path of the defect propagation (Asprone et al., 2014).

As the hydroxyl ions and the SieOeSi linkage react, the space between the cementmatrix and the BF increases, the interface layer of the cement paste becomes looser, and the bonding force between the fibers and the matrix decreases (Jiang et al., 2014).
The main reason is that NS particles react with CH in the matrix prior to the BF to form CeSeH gel, and the content of OH in the matrix decreases correspondingly (Khaloo et al., 2016).
This phenomenon is the same as that observed in the literature (Li et al., 2016), which shows that the pores become smaller and the pore content decreases after adding an appropriate amount of NS.
The new CeSeH gel leads to the reduction of the size and the content of CH crystal (Khaloo et al., 2016).
The flocculent CeSeH gel is tightly bonded to the compound layer (Pang et al., 2016), which strengthens the bond between the matrix and the fiber and improves the performance of the ITZ.

Due to the limited space, CH crystals cannot be fully developed, and the amount of crystal decreases, resulting in the decrease in the crystal and the strengthening gel; and the increasing in the concrete shrinkage creep (Khaloo et al., 2016); therefore, the internal structure of the concrete is looser.
The research shows that the intensity of the diffraction peak of a certain crystal phase decreases as the relative content of the crystal decreases (Khaloo et al., 2016).

metadata.abstractText: Use of recycled aggregate manufactured from waste concrete to produce new concrete could reduce the use of natural gravel, and the quantity and area of landfills, which is conducive to natural environmental protection and economic development. How to effectively reduce the hazards of construction waste is an urgent problem to be solved. Recycled aggregate concrete is one of the effective ways to realize the utilization of resources. This paper provides a new method for the resource utilization of construction waste, which is helpful for expanding the range of engineering applications for recycled aggregate concrete. The recycled aggregate concrete was reinforced with basalt fiber and nano-silica, and its mechanical properties, including compressive strength, splitting tensile strength and flexural strength were tested. Meanwhile, the microstructure of the recycled aggregate concrete was analyzed by scanning electron microscopy (SEM), X-ray diffraction (XRD) and energy dispersive spectroscopy (EDS). It was found that basalt fibers and nano-silica improve the recycled aggregate concrete. Nano-silica is beneficial for enhancing the bonding of the basalt fibers and cement matrix. The appropriate content of nano-silica was conducive to the improvement of the recycled aggregate concrete density and the performance of the interface transition zone, thereby increasing the bridge effect of the fibers. When the nano-silica content was high, the calcium-silicon ratio increased, and the concrete density decreased. In terms of the compressive strength and microstructures, when the recycled aggregate replacement ratio was no more than 50%, the optimum nano-silica content was 6%, and when the recycled aggregate replacement ratio was 100%, the optimum nano-silica content was 8%. The addition of basalt fiber and nano-silica is conducive to expanding the scope of engineering applications for recycled aggregate concrete and improving the natural environment, which is helpful to the sustainability of the construction industry. © 2019 Elsevier Ltd. All rights reserved.
metadata.creator: Elsevier
